title: 114_s2655
content: The "Historic Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2015" increases the rehabilitation credit for certain small projects. The Historic Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2015 increases the rehabilitation credit for small projects by substituting '30 percent' for '20 percent' in certain cases, with a maximum credit limit of $750,000. The term 'small project' refers to a certified historic structure with total qualified rehabilitation expenditures not exceeding $3,750,000 and no credit allowed in the two previous taxable years. The amendment applies to periods after the enactment of the Act. The curr_chunk states that rules similar to section 48(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will apply to periods after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. ALLOWANCE FOR THE TRANSFER OF CREDITS FOR CERTAIN SMALL PROJECTS. Section 47(e) of the Internal Revenue Code allows taxpayers to transfer a portion of the credit for a small project to another taxpayer, subject to certification requirements. Tax identification number, transferee's name, address, completion date, credit amount, and additional required information must be provided for credit transfer. The credit can only be transferred once and no deduction is allowed for consideration paid for the transfer. The transferee can receive a credit under this paragraph, which cannot be claimed by the transferor. The transferee can use the credit in the year it is transferred. Special rules apply for recapture and smaller projects. The amendments made by this section apply to periods after December 31, 2015. Transferor and transferee must report the transfer of credit as required by the Secretary. SEC. 4 amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the type of buildings eligible for rehabilitation by adjusting the basis. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2015. SEC. 5 reduces the basis adjustment for rehabilitation property. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust the rules for the rehabilitation credit, limiting the credit to 50 percent and coordinating with basis adjustment for property eligible for the credit. The amendments adjust the rules for the rehabilitation credit, limiting it to 50 percent and coordinating with basis adjustment for eligible property. The income of the lessee will include 50 percent of the credit allowable under section 38, ratably over the shortest recovery period. Effective date is for taxable years after enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. SPECIAL RULES FOR DISPOSITIONS OF STATE HISTORIC TAX CREDITS. This section introduces new rules for the disposition of state historic tax credits under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section introduces rules for taxpayers who receive and transfer State historic tax credits, stating that the net proceeds from such transactions do not count as income and reduce the taxpayer's basis in the property. The reduction in basis for State historic tax credits is applied first to the land, then to any building not considered a qualified rehabilitation expenditure, and finally to the remaining property basis. Adjustments in basis also apply to partnership interests and S corporation stock. The reduction in basis for State historic tax credits applies to land, buildings, and other property. Adjustments also affect partnership interests and S corporation stock. Taxpayers can elect to include net proceeds as income instead of following subsection (a). The election to include net proceeds as income instead of following subsection (a) can be made with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury. The transfer or allocation of State historic tax credits will not affect the rehabilitation credit allowable to a taxpayer under section 47. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of State historic tax credit for recapture provisions. It defines the credit as allowable under State or local laws for property rehabilitation expenditures. The table of sections in the Internal Revenue Code is also amended. The curr_chunk discusses modifications regarding certain tax-exempt use property, specifically amending Section 47(c)(2)(B)(v)(I) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act.
